seg.seg: in the mosäk of the night - pātayantika. In the first [part] of the night, ...

p.note: glosses Skt. /// [c]ch· t[ā] /// (23 reads /// + + + + + [h]ṇ. .. + + ///). This unclear gloss is followed by illegible traces of two more akṣaras that may belong to a next gloss.

This is certainly the indication of a certain point in time. 23 reads /// + + + + + takāla[s]· /// and considers to restore to hemaṃtakālasamaye 'in the winter time'. However, as pointed out by Klaus Wille (p.c.), the akṣara preceding ta is certainly not maṃ (nor ma). Also, the akṣara ta itself may actually rather be na. Although twāṣluneśi praṣtā 'at the time of lighting' seems to make sense in itself, the spelling is problematic: we would rather expect twāsluneṣi praṣtā. The large blank space before twā seems to exclude the restoration of a preceding syllable (e.g. (ri)twāṣluneśi praṣtā for (ri)twāṣsluneṣi praṣtā 'at the time of arrangement').

For the glossed word, 23 reads /// + + .r. .. .c(a) rātryā pratha[me] ///. In view of TA wṣeyis 'of the night' in the gloss, the first Sanskrit akṣara [t]r· is almost certainly to be restored as a form of rātri. Since the following rātryā prathame refers to a certain time of the night, this will be an indication of time as well, for instance (madhyarā)tr(au) 'in the middle of the night', a possible restoration according to the remaining akṣara traces. Unfortunately, TA moskoṃ is unclear. Assumedly, it is a locative, that is, for expected moskaṃ* 'get lost', a meaning like 'end (of the night)' could be envisaged (cf. ururātri 'the latter portion of the night', pāścāttyarātrau 'towards the end of the night'). The second correspondence is straightforward, but the spelling mältowinu (or its locative) 'first' for maltowinu is remarkable.

For the glossed word, 24 reads /// + + + + + vadāha[yi] ///, but in Peyrot's view (140), [ye] instead of [yi] must be read. The word is probably dāhaye(t) 'if he burns [it]' or (a)vadāhaye(t) 'if he burns [it] down'. The final -ṣiṣ points to a 3sg.opt.caus., compare for instance lyutkāṣiṣ 'he would turn into', but the root has unfortunately been lost completely. On the basis of the Sanskrit text, a verb for 'burn' would be expected. A number of verbs qualify: tsäk- 'burn', pälk- (caus.) 'burn, torment', and perhaps twāsā- 'burn' (no causative attested so far) and sälp- (caus.) 'make glow'. Of these, tsäk- seems to be the most neutral verb for 'burn', and the traces of the akṣara preceding ṣi appear to fit a reading (tskā)ṣiṣ\ best. It should, however, be noted that if this restoration is correct, the causative of tsäk- does not follow the pattern of näk-s- (tr.), as suggested in 842, but rather that of the much more frequent causatives with a subjunctive stem in -āṣä/sa-. On the basis of the following pa(t) of the gloss, Skt. vā 'or' may be assumed to have been lost after the verb.
